snippet: The donors at an international conference insisted for the first time that the Afghan government resist corruption in order to receive all the money.
abstract: International donor's conference in Tokyo pledges $16 billion for the economic development of Afghanistan in the next four years, but for the first time calls for stronger anticorruption measures in return; the money pledge, along with the plans for the Afghan security forces laid out at a NATO summit meeting in May in Chicago, represent a diplomatic success for American officials, who have lobbied for long-term international support for Afghanistan.

byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg contributed reporting from Kabul, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: The donors at an international conference insisted for the first time that the Afghan government resist corruption in order to receive all the money.
